ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have developed an, I would say, elementary working proficiency in German  being able to recognize a variety of vocabulary as well as grammatical structures and sentence patterns.
Rigorous introduction to German grammar, syntax, reading/translating skills, also some cultural background through the assigned text translations
I learned how to translate German texts, practicing vocabulary and grammar for texts related to my field of study.

This was my first time studying German, so this course was my only introduction so far to it. I would not say I can now read and understand German fluently, but I definitely have a good grasp of grammar, syntax, and constructions that are specific to German. I also learned how to use paper and online dictionaries as well as a variety of facts about German culture and history.
attention to details, new language reading ability, broad German history knowledge
Reading capabilities in German to be able to conduct primary research. Also the ability to understand when and how I should intelligently consult a dictionary rather than looking up every word.
I worked on my german translation abilities.

Taking this course greatly improved my grammar and vocabulary in German. Already, I have noticed improvements in my ability to work with primary and secondary sources in German, which is necessary for my research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: organic progression of content; short chapter readings that made it feel more manageable; asynchronous allowed for flexibility in completion
Weaknesses: lectures were pretty much repetitions of the readings, and I would've preferred more new material/examples; some of the grading notes could be explained a bit more, primarily when the correction is to a word or phrase that seems content-wise synonymous with what was "corrected"

The course was executed well in a self-paced, module-based format. Feedback was always prompt, individualized, and helpful. Some lectures might have benefitted from more examples that were not already included the textbook.
The structure was a strength - constantly translating helped develop skills quickly and efficiently. Some individual time with the professor would have been helpful.

Strengths: the breadth of the material covered in the book, the rigor and clarity in the presentation of grammar rules; the variety of themes and subjects that the translations dealt with; the clear and prompt feedback offered by the instructor and the TA.

Weaknesses: the lack of a "live" component i.e. a weekly Q&A session or walk-in office hours led by the instructor where one could ask questions, share one's struggles, and exchange learning tips with classmates.
it being 100% online was stressful and less engaging than it could have been
I thought the course went quite well.  I really enjoyed the self paced aspect and the recorded lectures allowed the perfect amount of aid when the chapter in the textbook was a bit too confusing.

The course had a lot of work which meant so much more time was spent just getting it done than really working on the nitty gritty of the grammar and the vocabulary so fewer daily assignments would be better. The textbook and video lessons were very helpful.
It's an online language course, it seems well-structured for what it is. Any "weaknesses" are likely inherent to the form of online, asynchronous, text-only language instruction.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it provided what was promised.

Yes, if you would like to learn German (for reading/research purposes, NOT for conversation). By the end of the course, you will have gained a basic knowledge of German grammar and will be prepared to begin accessing German scholarship in your field - very exciting!
Absolutely - a very efficient way to learn a new language

I would recommend this course to a fellow student but also give them the heads up that it a very time-consuming and challenging course, especially if one has never studied German before. Encountering a language for the first time can be very frustrating and a fully online course with no live component comes with an additional layer of challenges and frustrations.
Yes
Yes.  My university does not offer German reading courses regularly, but my program requires reading exams and this course was perfect to get me prepared for them.
Yes, I would if one needed to just read German. To really understand the language I think it would be better to take an introductory class.
Yes, I would recommend this to any other graduate students looking to learn the basics of German or to improve on their reading comprehension/speed.
yes
